Quartz

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”4.4.7″ custom_padding=”0px||0px|||” collapsed=”on” global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_row column_structure=”1_3,2_3″ use_custom_gutter=”on” gutter_width=”2″ _builder_version=”4.4.7″ width=”90%” max_width=”95%” module_alignment=”center” custom_padding=”54px||13px||false|false” global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”4.4.7″ border_width_right=”1px” border_color_right=”#ffffff” global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_image src=”https://www.gmciltd.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Quartz-Powder.jpg” title_text=”Quartz Powder” align_tablet=”center” align_phone=”center” align_last_edited=”on|tablet” _builder_version=”4.4.7″ custom_padding=”||0px|||” animation_style=”slide” animation_direction=”left” scroll_horizontal_motion=”0|50|50|100|4|0|0″ global_colors_info=”{}” filter_hue_rotate__hover_enabled=”off|desktop” filter_hue_rotate__hover=”31deg”][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”2_3″ _builder_version=”4.4.7″ global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.4.7″ text_font=”Lato|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#004B4F” text_font_size=”19px” text_letter_spacing=”0.5px” text_line_height=”2.2em” custom_padding_tablet=”” custom_padding_phone=”20px||||false|false” custom_padding_last_edited=”on|phone” scroll_horizontal_motion=”0|67|67|100|4|0|-4″ text_text_color_tablet=”” text_text_color_phone=”” text_text_color_last_edited=”on|phone” text_font_size_tablet=”19px” text_font_size_phone=”17px” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|phone” text_orientation_tablet=”center” text_orientation_phone=”center” text_orientation_last_edited=”on|tablet” global_colors_info=”{}”]

QUARTZ is a strong, crystalline mineral made up of silicon and oxygen atoms and the second most common mineral in the planet’s crust after the feldspar series of minerals. Quartz crystals, which are hexagonal in form, differ widely in size and colour. This flexible mineral is both robust and chemically inert and has outstanding heat resistance and electrical properties.

Quartz is a defining element of granite and other igneous felsic rocks. Sedimentary rocks including sandstones and shales as well as shale, gneiss, quartzite and other metamorphic rocks are natural.
Our quartz comes in all forms from 100, 150, 200, 250, 325 & 500 BSS mesh, grain & fine powder.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row column_structure=”1_3,1_3,1_3″ use_custom_gutter=”on” gutter_width=”2″ _builder_version=”4.4.7″ width=”90%” max_width=”95%” module_alignment=”center” custom_padding=”5px||24px||false|false” global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”4.4.7″ border_width_right=”1px” border_color_right=”#ffffff” global_colors_info=”{}”][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”4.4.7″ global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.4.7″ text_font=”Lato|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#004b4f” text_font_size=”18px” text_letter_spacing=”0.5px” text_line_height=”1.6em” header_font=”|||on|||||” header_6_font=”Lato|700||on|||||” header_6_text_color=”#004b4f” header_6_font_size=”25px” header_6_line_height=”1.5em” custom_padding=”0px||||false|false” custom_padding_tablet=”|||20px|false|false” custom_padding_phone=”20px|||20px|false|false” custom_padding_last_edited=”on|tablet” scroll_horizontal_motion=”0|67|67|100|4|0|-4″ text_text_color_tablet=”” text_text_color_phone=”” text_text_color_last_edited=”on|phone” text_font_size_tablet=”19px” text_font_size_phone=”17px” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|phone” header_6_font_size_tablet=”24px” header_6_font_size_phone=”24px” header_6_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop” text_orientation_tablet=”left” text_orientation_phone=”left” text_orientation_last_edited=”on|tablet” global_colors_info=”{}”]

Physical properties
  • Hard (7 on MOHS scale)
  • Chemically inert
  • Thermal stability
  • Electrical properties
  • Iron fe203 at 0.03%.
  • Melting Temperature – 1350° c

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”4.4.7″ global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.4.7″ text_font=”Lato|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#004B4F” text_font_size=”18px” text_letter_spacing=”0.5px” text_line_height=”1.6em” header_6_font=”Lato|700|||||||” header_6_text_color=”#004b4f” header_6_font_size=”25px” header_6_line_height=”1.5em” custom_padding=”||||false|false” custom_padding_tablet=”|||20px|false|false” custom_padding_phone=”20px|||20px|false|false” custom_padding_last_edited=”on|tablet” scroll_horizontal_motion=”0|67|67|100|4|0|-4″ text_text_color_tablet=”” text_text_color_phone=”” text_text_color_last_edited=”on|phone” text_font_size_tablet=”19px” text_font_size_phone=”17px” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|phone” header_6_font_size_tablet=”24px” header_6_font_size_phone=”24px” header_6_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop” text_orientation_tablet=”left” text_orientation_phone=”left” text_orientation_last_edited=”on|tablet” global_colors_info=”{}”]

APPLICATION
  • Glass industry sued as abrasive in sand blasting
  • Used as foundry sand in refractory bricks
  • Petroleum industry
  • Artificial sands for baseball fields and volleyball courts
  • High quality gemstone production.
